channel.title: D Link on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!
channel.description: Recent content in D Link on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!

item.title: Como Configurar a Gravação da D-Link DCS-5010L com FTP
item.description:
D-Link 5010L

A câmera D-Link DCS 5010L é um dos modelos mais populares da D-Link com visão noturna, rotação horizontal e vertical, WiFi e funciona com o serviço MyDlink. O valor da DCS-5010L é também muito acessível: atualmente ela custa $75 na Amazon. Esta câmera é muito parecida com a DCS-5020L, mas custa quase metade do preço.

Necessidade de Gravação

Apesar do serviço MyDlink permitir que você veja essa câmera remotamente, ele não suporta nenhum tipo de gravação ou armazenamento de imagens. É aqui que o Sensr.net entra. Nosso serviço permite armazenar automaticamente as imagens captadas no último mês. Este artigo vai ajudar você a configurar sua câmera DCS-5010L para que você veja tudo o que se passa com as suas coisas enquanto você não está olhando!

Também vou mostrar como configurar a câmera para enviar imagens para o site do Sensr.net, para que você tire partido de todas as funcionalidades do nosso serviço, como o armazenamento, o compartilhamento, e os alertas.

Resumo

  1. Configure o seu serviço MyDlink
  2. Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net
  3. Apresente o Sensr.net à sua câmera

Detalhes

Passo 1: Para configurar a câmera, utilize o CD e as instruções disponibilizados em conjunto com a câmera. Tudo o que você precisa de fazer é conectar a câmera ao seu roteador e correr o software do CD. Você vai acabar por criar uma conta no site do MyDlink que vai dar acesso à sua câmera a partir do site ou dos aplicativos MyDlink. Após este passo, você conseguirá acessar sua câmera e alterar suas configurações. A página de configuração de sua câmera vai ter mais ou menos esse aspeto:

Página Admin DCS-5010L

Agora você já consegue fazer alterações às configurações da câmera através do seu navegador. Se o que você pretende é assistir às filmagens em tempo real a partir de sua casa ou através do site MyDlink, então não será necessário fazer mais nada. (Existem outras configurações, como conexão sem fios e tamanho da imagem, que você pode alterar diretamente na interface, mas que eu não vou abordar nesse artigo.)

Adicione uma nova câmera à sua conta Sensr.net

Passo 2: Faça o login no Sensr.net, utilizando o seu email e a sua senha. Se ainda não possui uma conta, você pode criar uma gratuitamente na página de inscrição. Depois de fazer login, clique no botão verde Add Camera.

Clique no botão verde

Na página seguinte, você vai poder escolher o título (ou nome) da câmera, o fuso horário, a privacidade e o modelo. O título deve descrever o que a câmera está filmando. O título mais popular no Sensr.net é Porta da Frente, que nos dá uma ideia de como os usuários utilizam o nosso site. Apesar de nós gerarmos um nome genérico para sua câmera baseado no login, você pode dar qualquer nome à sua câmera. O fuso horário é muito importante. Ele é utilizado para determinar a vista diária dos arquivos. Por padrão, as câmeras são privadas, o que significa que apenas você tem acesso a elas. Se quiser que sua câmera seja pública, você pode alterar essa configuração aqui. O modelo da câmera apenas indica qual o modelo que está sendo configurado. Nesse caso, o modelo é DCS-5010L.

Dê um nome à sua câmera e compartilhe alguns detalhes

Depois de preencher todos os detalhes e clicar no link Next Step, nós vamos criar algumas credenciais FTP para você. Será necessário introduzir esses dados na sua câmera no próximo passo. Os dados com mais importância são:

  1. Servidor FTP
  2. Nome de usuário
  3. Senha

Mantenha essa janela aberta ou copie os dados, uma vez que você vai precisar deles em breve. Você pode recuperar esses dados, a qualquer momento, na página de detalhes da câmera.

Credenciais FTP

Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net

Passo 3: Agora é necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net. Volte à página da DCS-5010L, fazendo o login no site MyDlink e clicando no link de configuração. Clique em “SETUP” no menu superior e, depois, em “FTP”, na lateral. Você vai ser encaminhado para essa página:

Página Configuração FTP DCS-5010L

As setas vermelhas mostram os parâmetros que devem ser configurados. No campo Host Name, introduza o servidor FTP que fornecemos na página “Add Camera” no Sensr.net. Copie também o usuário e a senha. Escolha “Passive Mode”, uma vez que o Sensr.net suporta apenas o modo FTP passivo.

É também necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net periodicamente. Para isso, selecione “Enable uploading to the FTP server” e confirme que “Always” e “1 Frames/Second” estão também selecionados. Estas são as configurações padrão e funcionam bem com o Sensr.net. As configurações padrão para o nome do ficheiro também são bem suportadas pelo serviço, por isso não existe necessidade de alterar.

Não se esqueça de clicar no botão “Save Settings” localizado no topo da página. Após realizar este passo, a sua câmera DCS-5010L já estará enviando imagens para o Sensr.net.

Agora a configuração está terminada. Pode fechar a janela do navegador que mostra as configurações de sua câmera e voltar para o Sensr.net. Clique no botão Next Step para ver as imagens enviadas pela sua câmera. Você verá uma página assim:

Sucesso!

Agora que a sua câmera já está configurada, existem outras coisas que você pode fazer:

  • Adicionar alertas de movimento por SMS ou email
  • Convidar outros usuários para ver a sua câmera
  • Incorporar o streaming de vídeo em tempo real no seu blog ou outro site
  • Criar um clipe de vídeo e compartilhar no Facebook, Twitter ou YouTube

Se tiver alguma dificuldade ou pergunta, clique no botão de Feedback no lado direito de qualquer uma das páginas do Sensr.net e coloque a sua questão. Geralmente, nós nos esforçamos por responder no prazo máximo de 24h horas.

item.title: Como Configurar a Gravação da D-Link DCS-5020L com Uploads FTP
item.description:
DCS-5020L da D-Link

A câmera D-Link DCS 5020L é um dos modelos mais populares da D-Link. Ela dispõe de visão noturna, rotação horizontal e vertical, WiFi e funciona com o serviço MyDlink. O valor da DCS 5020L é também muito acessível: atualmente ela custa $135 na Amazon.

Necessidade de Gravação

Apesar do serviço MyDlink permitir que você assista às filmagens da câmera remotamente, ele não suporta nenhum tipo de gravação ou armazenamento de imagens. É aqui que o Sensr.net entra. Nosso serviço permite armazenar automaticamente as imagens captadas no último mês. Este artigo vai ajudar você a configurar sua câmera DCS-5020L para que você veja tudo o que se passa com as suas coisas enquanto você não está olhando!

Também vou mostrar como configurar a câmera para enviar imagens para o site do

Sensr.net, para que você tire partido de todas as funcionalidades do nosso serviço, como o armazenamento, o compartilhamento, e os alertas.

Resumo

  1. Configure o seu serviço MyDlink
  2. Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net
  3. Apresente o Sensr.net à sua câmera

Detalhes

Passo 1: Para configurar a câmera, utilize o CD e as instruções disponibilizados em conjunto com o aparelho. Tudo o que você precisa de fazer é conectar a câmera ao seu roteador e correr o software do CD. Você vai acabar por criar uma conta no site do MyDlink que vai dar acesso à sua câmera a partir do site ou dos aplicativos MyDlink. Após este passo, você conseguirá acessar sua câmera e alterar suas configurações. A página de configuração de sua câmera vai ter mais ou menos esse aspeto:

Página de Admin da DCS-930L

Agora você já consegue fazer alterações às configurações da câmera através do seu navegador. Se o que você pretende é assistir às filmagens em tempo real a partir de sua casa ou através do site MyDlink, então não será necessário fazer mais nada. (Existem outras configurações, como conexão sem fios e tamanho da imagem, que você pode alterar diretamente na interface, mas que eu não vou abordar nesse artigo.)

Adicione uma nova câmera à sua conta Sensr.net

Passo 2: Faça o login no Sensr.net, utilizando o seu email e a sua senha. Se ainda não possui uma conta, você pode criar uma gratuitamente na página de inscrição. Depois de fazer login, clique no botão verde Add Camera.

Clique no botão verde

Na página seguinte, você vai poder escolher o título (ou nome) da câmera, o fuso horário, a privacidade e o modelo. O título deve descrever o que a câmera está filmando. O título mais popular no Sensr.net é Porta da Frente, que nos dá uma ideia de como os usuários utilizam o nosso site. Apesar de nós gerarmos um nome genérico para sua câmera baseado no login, você pode dar qualquer nome à sua câmera. O fuso horário é muito importante. Ele é utilizado para determinar a vista diária dos arquivos. Por padrão, as câmeras são privadas, o que significa que apenas você tem acesso a elas. Se quiser que sua câmera seja pública, você pode alterar essa configuração aqui. O modelo da câmera apenas indica qual o modelo que está sendo configurado. Nesse caso, o modelo é DCS-5020L.

Dê um nome à sua câmera e compartilhe alguns detalhes

Depois de preencher todos os detalhes e clicar no link Next Step, nós vamos criar algumas credenciais FTP para você. Será necessário introduzir esses dados na sua câmera no próximo passo. Os dados com mais importância são:

  1. Servidor FTP
  2. Nome de usuário
  3. Senha

Mantenha essa janela aberta ou copie os dados, uma vez que você vai precisar deles em breve. Você pode recuperar esses dados, a qualquer momento, na página de detalhes da câmera.

Credenciais FTP

Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net

Passo 3: Agora é necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net. Volte à página da DCS-5020L, fazendo o login no site MyDlink e clicando no link de configuração. Clique em “SETUP” no menu superior e, depois, em “FTP”, na lateral. Você vai ser encaminhado para essa página:

DCS-5020L Página de configuração FTP

As setas vermelhas mostram os parâmetros que devem ser configurados. No campo Host Name, introduza o servidor FTP que fornecemos na página “Add Camera” no Sensr.net. Copie também o usuário e a senha. Escolha “Passive Mode”, uma vez que o Sensr.net suporta apenas o modo FTP passivo.

É também necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net periodicamente. Para isso, selecione “Enable uploading to the FTP server” e confirme que “Always” e “1 Frames/Second” estão também selecionados. Estas são as configurações padrão e funcionam bem com o Sensr.net. As configurações padrão para o nome do ficheiro também são bem suportadas pelo serviço, por isso não existe necessidade de alterar.

Não se esqueça de clicar no botão “Save Settings” localizado no topo da página. Após realizar este passo, a sua câmera DCS-5020L já estará enviando imagens para o Sensr.net.

Agora a configuração está terminada. Pode fechar a janela do navegador que mostra as configurações de sua câmera e voltar para o Sensr.net. Clique no botão Next Step para ver as imagens enviadas pela sua câmera. Você verá uma página assim:

Sucesso!

Agora que a sua câmera já está configurada, existem outras coisas que você pode fazer:

  • Adicionar alertas de movimento por SMS ou email
  • Convidar outros usuários para ver a sua câmera
  • Incorporar o streaming de vídeo em tempo real no seu blog ou outro site
  • Criar um clipe de vídeo e compartilhar no Facebook, Twitter ou YouTube

Se tiver alguma dificuldade ou pergunta, clique no botão de Feedback no lado direito de qualquer uma das páginas do Sensr.net e coloque a sua questão. Nós tentaremos responder no prazo máximo de 24h horas.

Divirta-se!

item.title: Setup Cloud Recording with the D-Link 931L and Sensr.net
item.description:
D-Link 931L

The D-Link 931L is the little brother of the D-Link 933L. While the 931L still has many of the functions of the 933L, including the wifi repeater which greatly increases it’s range, it does not have night vision. While this has some obvious security limitations it also means the 931L is $30 cheaper (the 931 currently goes for $39.99 on amazon). The best part about these two camera’s is they have the same setup and are both perfect for Sensr.net’s cloud recording system! If you want to learn how to setup the D-Link 931L or the DCS-933L just visit this tutorial here.

item.title: How to Setup the D-Link DCS-933L and use it with Sensr.net
item.description:
The D-Link DCS-933L

The D-Link DCS-933L is a great IP camera because of it’s price. It doesn’t pan or tilt  which means you have less options when you choose where to put it and you will have to go physically move the camera anytime you want to change where it is looking but you do save some money. The DCS-933L also has night vision which is obviously very important if you are hoping to use your camera for security purposes. The setup here is pretty similar to the rest of the DCS-900 series. We have a tutorial for setting up the DCS-930L. With this tutorial you should be able to get this camera set up quickly and easily.

I’ll also show you how to push images to Sensr.net so you can take advantage of all of our cool features, like SMS and email alerts, 30 days archiving, no firewall config, clip sharing, embedable live streams, guest access, etc.

This setup involves four steps:

  1. Plug in your DCS-933L  and connect it to the internet.
  2. Access your DCS-933L through your web browser
  3. Add a new Camera on Sensr.net
  4. Enter your new FTP credentials into your DCS-933L

When you are connecting your camera to the internet you have two choices: wired or wireless. Wireless is possible if your router supports WPS connections. To establish a wireless connection plug in your camera and hold down the WPS button on the back of your camera; the blue WPS status light will start blinking. You now have sixty seconds to press the WPS button on your wireless router which will be located either somewhere on the router or on the router’s web access page.

If your router does not support WPS then you will need to plug in via an ethernet connection. Simply plug your camera’s power cord into a normal wall outlet and ethernet port into a normal ethernet connection.

Access your DCS-933L through your web browser:

Once you are hooked up to an internet connection just go to your routers access page by typing the IP address of your router into your internet browser. You can find the IP address of your router on your computers settings. On my mac I go to to Network Settings > Advanced > TCP/IP, and it looks like this:

Once you are on your router’s access page just look for the new item and grab the IP address. This is the IP address of your DCS-933L. Enter that into your browser and it will bring you to D-Link’s network access page. It will ask you for a username and password which are admin and admin. You should change those. It should look something like this:

DCS-930L’s Admin page

With access to this page you can make the changes to the camera you will need to use it with Sensr.net. Keep this page open and go to a new tab and open your Sensr.net account.

Add a new Camera on Sensr.net:

Login to Sensr.net using your email and password.  If you don’t have an account, you can add one for free on the sign up page.  Once you’re logged in, just click the Add Camera button in green:

Next you will see a page asking you to give some information about the camera. Some of this stuff is important as it helps get the schedule right. The rest is important because it will help you know which camera is which should you choose to add more. It should look like this:

Name your camera and give us some basic info about it.

Once you press next step it will take you to a page giving you your new FTP credentials. These are very important and make it so your camera will know to send the images to us. The page will look like this:

FTP credentials

Keep this page open so you won’t forget the credentials. Of course you can always open this page again should you accidentally close it.

Enter your new FTP credentials into your DCS-933L:

Go back to the Network Access page for your DCS-933L. Click on “SETUP” on the top menu and then “FTP” on the side.  You’ll then be at a page that looks like this:

DCS-5010L FTP setup page

The red arrows above show the settings you need to configure.  Under Host Name add the FTP server name you got from the add camera page on sensr.net.  Copy the user name and password as well.  Make sure to select “Passive Mode”,  we only support passive FTP on Sensr.net.

You also need to tell your camera to send images to Sensr.net on a schedule.  You do this by selecting the check box “Enable uploading to the FTP server” and confirm that “Always” and “1 Frames/Second”

are selected.    These are the defaults and seem to work well.  The other default’s for the file name are also well supported, so no reason to change them.

Make sure to click the “Save Settings” button at the top of the page.

At this point you are done. You can close the browser window pointed at your camera and go back to Sensr.net. Click on the Next Step button to see the images coming in from your camera. You should see a page something like this:

Waiting for upload

To this:

Success!

Now that you have the camera setup, here are some other things you can do:

  • Add motion alerts via SMS or email
  • Invite guests to view your private camera
  • Embed the live stream on your blog or other website
  • Create a clip and share it on Facebook, Twitter, or YouTube

If you have any problems or questions, just click the Feedback button on the right side of every Sensr.net page and ask us a question.  We usually respond quickly and try hard to get back within 24 hours at the latest.

item.title: How to setup the D-Link DCS-5222L and use it with Sensr.net
item.description:
D-link DCS 522L

The D-Link DCS-522L is one of the most popular cameras on amazon and is great of use with Sensr.net. The DCS-522L has a ton of great features like night vision and pan/tilt. It also records HD video which is an awesome plus. Setup is pretty much the same as all of the DCS-5000 series so this will look a lot like some of our other posts.

Why use Sensr.net?

D-Link has their own web-based viewing service called MyDlink. While this service does allow for remote viewing it does not record the feed. Sensr.net will automatically save up to a months worth of data on our servers so you can see what happens when you’re not looking. Sensr.net also has a bunch of other cool features so you can

  • Add motion alerts via SMS or email
  • Invite guests to view your private camera
  • Embed the live stream on your blog or other website
  • Create a clip and share it on Facebook, Twitter, or YouTube

Overview

  1. Setup your MyDlink Service
  2. Tell Sensr.net about your camera
  3. Tell your camera about Sensr.net

Step 1:  To setup the camera out of the box, just use the CD and instructions that come with the camera. Basically you’ll need to connect the camera to your router and run some software from the CD.  You’ll end up creating an account on the MyDlink site that will let you log into your camera through their website or using the MyDlink apps.  Once you have that setup, you’ll be able to log into your camera and change it’s configurations.  You’ll be able to see the camera’s configuration page which looks something like this:

DCS-930L Admin page

You can now make changes to your camera’s config through your browser. You don’t need to do anything else if you just want to view the camera live inside your home or through the MyDlink website. (There are other configs like wireless and image size, all of which you can get to through the web interface, I’m not going to cover them here.)

Add a New Camera to your Sensr.net Account

Step 2 Login to Sensr.net using your email and password.  If you don’t have an account, you can add one for free on the sign up page.  Once you’re logged in, just click the Add Camerabutton in green.

Next you’ll see a page where you can set the camera’s title, the time zone, privacy, and model.  The Title should give you some sort of idea where your camera is just to keep you organized should you add more cameras. The time zone is necessary because it is used to create the day view of the archives.  Cameras are private by default, meaning only you can see them.  If you want your camera to be public, you can change that setting here.  The camera model just tells us what kind of camera you’re setting up.  In this case it would be a DCS-5222L.

Once you fill in the details and click the Next Step link we’ll generate some FTP credentials for you. You’ll need to put these into your camera in the next step. You’ll need the FTP Server, the Username, and the Password.

Keep this window open or copy and paste them somewhere since you’ll need them soon.  You can always find them later if you need them again or loose them.  They’ll be under the camera’s details page.

 

Tell your Camera about Sensr.net

Step 3  Now you just need to let your camera know to start uploading to Sensr.net.  Go back to the page for your DCS-5222L.  You can get here by logging into MyDlink and clicking on the configuration link.  Click on “SETUP” on the top menu and then “FTP” on the side.  The page should be something like this:

DCS-5020L FTP setup page

The red arrows above show the settings you need to configure.  Under Host Name copy and paste the FTP server name you got from Sensr.net.  Copy the user name and password as well.  Make sure to select “Passive Mode”,  we only support passive FTP on Sensr.net.

You also need to tell your camera to send images to Sensr.net on a schedule.  You do this by selecting the check box “Enable uploading to the FTP server” and confirm that “Always” and “1 Frames/Second”

are selected.    These are the defaults and seem to work well.  The other default’s for the file name are also well supported, so no reason to change them.

Make sure to click the “Save Settings” button at the top of the page.  Once you’ve done this, your DCS-5222L should be sending images to Sensr.net.

Now you are done. If you click next step on the Sensr.net page you should get to a page showing you your camera feed like this:

Now that you have the camera setup, you can do all sorts of things like:

  • Add motion alerts via SMS or email
  • Invite guests to view your private camera
  • Embed the live stream on your blog or other website
  • Create a clip and share it on Facebook, Twitter, or YouTube

If you have any problems or questions, just click the Feedback button on the right side of every Sensr.net page or send an email to info@sensr.net and ask us a question.  We usually respond quickly and try hard to get back within 24 hours at the latest.

Have fun!

item.title: HOWTO Setup D-Link DCS-5010L Recording with FTP
item.description:
D-Link 5010L

The D-Link DCS 5010L is one of their most popular camera models with night vision, pan and tilt, WiFi and it works with the mydlink service.  The DCS 5010L is also very affordable at around $75 on Amazon these days. This camera compares to the DCS-5020L at almost twice the price.

I’ll also show you how to push images to Sensr.net so you can take advantage of all of our cool features, like SMS and email alerts, 30 days archiving, no firewall config, clip sharing, embedable live streams, guest access, etc.

Recording Needed

While the MyDlink service will let you view this camera remotely, it doesn’t support any kind of recording or saving of images. That’s where Sensr.net comes in.  We’ll save up to a month of archives automatically.  This blog post will show you how to setup the DCS-5010L so you can see what happened while you weren’t looking!

I’ll also show you how to configure the camera to push images to the Sensr.net site so you can take advantage of all the cool Sensr.net features like archiving, sharing, and alerting that our site provides.

Overview

  1. Setup your MyDlink Service
  2. Tell Sensr.net about your camera
  3. Tell your camera about Sensr.net

Details

Step 1:  To setup the camera out of the box, just use the CD and instructions that come with the camera. Basically you’ll need to connect the camera to your router and run some software from the CD.  You’ll end up creating an account on the MyDlink site that will let you log into your camera through their website or using the MyDlink apps.  Once you have that setup, you’ll be able to log into your camera and change it’s configurations.  You’ll be able to see the camera’s configuration page which looks something like this:

DCS-5010L Admin page

You can now make changes to your camera’s config through your browser. You don’t need to do anything else if you just want to view the camera live inside your home or through the MyDlink website. (There are other configs like wireless and image size, all of which you can get to through the web interface, I’m not going to cover them here.)

Add a New Camera to your Sensr.net Account

Step 2 Login to Sensr.net using your email and password.  If you don’t have an account, you can add one for free on the sign up page.  Once you’re logged in, just click the Add Camera button in green.

Click the green button.

Next you’ll see a page where you can set the camera’s title, the time zone, privacy, and model.  The title should be something that describes what the camera is pointing at.  The most popular camera title on Sensr.net is Front Door so this gives you an idea of how folks are using our site. You can name the camera whatever you want though, we generate a generic name based on your login. The time zone is pretty important.  It’s used to generate the day view of the archives.  Cameras are private by default, meaning only you can see them.  If you want your camera to be public, you can change that setting here.  The camera model just tells us what kind of camera you’re setting up.  In this case it would be a DCS-5010L.

Name your camera and give us some basic info about it.

Once you fill in the details and click the Next Step link we’ll generate some FTP credentials for you. You’ll need to put these into your camera in the next step.  The important things are:

  1. FTP Server
  2. Username
  3. Password

Keep this window open or copy and paste them somewhere since you’ll need them soon.  You can always get them back later if you need them again or loose them.  They’ll be under the camera’s details page.

FTP credentials

 

Tell your Camera about Sensr.net

Step 3  Now you need to configure your camera so it will send images to sensr.net.  Go back to the page for your DCS-5010L.  You can get here by logging into MyDlink and clicking on the configuration link.  Click on “SETUP” on the top menu and then “FTP” on the side.  You’ll then be at a page that looks like this:

DCS-5010L FTP setup page

The red arrows above show the settings you need to configure.  Under Host Name add the FTP server name you got from the add camera page on sensr.net.  Copy the user name and password as well.  Make sure to select “Passive Mode”,  we only support passive FTP on Sensr.net.

You also need to tell your camera to send images to Sensr.net on a schedule.  You do this by selecting the check box “Enable uploading to the FTP server” and confirm that “Always” and “1 Frames/Second”

are selected.    These are the defaults and seem to work well.  The other default’s for the file name are also well supported, so no reason to change them.

Make sure to click the “Save Settings” button at the top of the page.  Once you’ve done this, your DCS-5010L should be sending images to Sensr.net.

At this point you are done. You can close the browser window pointed at your camera and go back to Sensr.net. Click on the Next Step button to see the images coming in from your camera. You should see a page something like this:

Success!

Now that you have the camera setup, here are some other things you can do:

  • Add motion alerts via SMS or email
  • Invite guests to view your private camera
  • Embed the live stream on your blog or other website
  • Create a clip and share it on Facebook, Twitter, or YouTube

Note that you can view the camera live on the Sensr.net site or the MyDlink site. With MyDlink you’ll be able to configure the camera and use the pan and tilt functions. On the Sensr.net site you’ll see recorded archives and setup alerts, create clips for sharing, save images to a favorites gallery and a whole lot more.

If you have any problems or questions, just click the Feedback button on the right side of every Sensr.net page and ask us a question.  We usually respond quickly and try hard to get back within 24 hours at the latest.

item.title: Setup D-Link DCS-5020L Recording with FTP Uploads HOWTO
item.description:
DCS-5020L from D-Link

The D-Link DCS 5020L is one of their more popular models of camera.  It has night vision, pan and tilt, WiFi and it works with the mydlink service.  The DCS 5020L is also pretty affordable at around $135 on Amazon these days.

Recording Needed

While the MyDlink service will let you view this camera remotely, it doesn’t support any kind of recording or saving of images. That’s where Sensr.net comes in.  We’ll save up to a month of archives automatically.  This blog post will show you how to setup the DCS-5020L so you can see what happened while you weren’t looking!

I’ll also show you how to push images to Sensr.net so you can take advantage of all of our cool features, SMS and email alerts, 30 days of archiving, no firewall config, clip sharing, embedable live streams, guest access, etc.

Overview

  1. Setup your MyDlink Service
  2. Tell Sensr.net about your camera
  3. Tell your camera about Sensr.net

Details

Step 1:  To setup the camera out of the box, just use the CD and instructions that come with the camera. Basically you’ll need to connect the camera to your router and run some software from the CD.  You’ll end up creating an account on the MyDlink site that will let you log into your camera through their website or using the MyDlink apps.  Once you have that setup, you’ll be able to log into your camera and change it’s configurations.  You’ll be able to see the camera’s configuration page which looks something like this:

DCS-930L Admin page

You can now make changes to your camera’s config through your browser. You don’t need to do anything else if you just want to view the camera live inside your home or through the MyDlink website. (There are other configs like wireless and image size, all of which you can get to through the web interface, I’m not going to cover them here.)

Add a New Camera to your Sensr.net Account

Step 2 Login to Sensr.net using your email and password.  If you don’t have an account, you can add one for free on the sign up page.  Once you’re logged in, just click the Add Camera button in green.

Click the green button.

Next you’ll see a page where you can set the camera’s title, the time zone, privacy, and model.  The title should be something that describes what the camera is pointing at.  The most popular camera title on Sensr.net is Front Door so this gives you an idea of how folks are using our site. You can name the camera whatever you want though, we generate a generic name based on your login. The time zone is pretty important.  It’s used to generate the day view of the archives.  Cameras are private by default, meaning only you can see them.  If you want your camera to be public, you can change that setting here.  The camera model just tells us what kind of camera you’re setting up.  In this case it would be a DCS-5020L.

Name your camera and give us some basic info about it.

Once you fill in the details and click the Next Step link we’ll generate some FTP credentials for you. You’ll need to put these into your camera in the next step.  The important things are:

  1. FTP Server
  2. Username
  3. Password

Keep this window open or copy and paste them somewhere since you’ll need them soon.  You can always get them back later if you need them again or loose them.  They’ll be under the camera’s details page.

FTP credentials

 

Tell your Camera about Sensr.net

Step 3  Now you need to configure your camera so it will send images to sensr.net.  Go back to the page for your DCS-5020L.  You can get here by logging into MyDlink and clicking on the configuration link.  Click on “SETUP” on the top menu and then “FTP” on the side.  You’ll then be at a page that looks like this:

DCS-5020L FTP setup page

The red arrows above show the settings you need to configure.  Under Host Name add the FTP server name you got from the add camera page on sensr.net.  Copy the user name and password as well.  Make sure to select “Passive Mode”,  we only support passive FTP on Sensr.net.

You also need to tell your camera to send images to Sensr.net on a schedule.  You do this by selecting the check box “Enable uploading to the FTP server” and confirm that “Always” and “1 Frames/Second”

are selected.    These are the defaults and seem to work well.  The other default’s for the file name are also well supported, so no reason to change them.

Make sure to click the “Save Settings” button at the top of the page.  Once you’ve done this, your DCS-5020L should be sending images to Sensr.net.

At this point you are done. You can close the browser window pointed at your camera and go back to Sensr.net. Click on the Next Step button to see the images coming in from your camera. You should see a page something like this:

Success!

Now that you have the camera setup, here are some other things you can do:

  • Add motion alerts via SMS or email
  • Invite guests to view your private camera
  • Embed the live stream on your blog or other website
  • Create a clip and share it on Facebook, Twitter, or YouTube

If you have any problems or questions, just click the Feedback button on the right side of every Sensr.net page and ask us a question.  We usually respond quickly and try hard to get back within 24 hours at the latest.

Have fun!

item.title: D-Link Cloud Cameras DCS 931L and DCS-933L Unveiled at CES 2013
item.description: D-Link announced two new cloud IP cameras, the DCS-931L and DCS-933L this week at CES, expanding on their MyDLink service. Also labeled as the Cloud Cameras 1050 and 1150 respectively, the two cameras are equipped with H.264 video compression, and a somewhat small 640×480 VGA resolution. The 1150 (DCS-933L) also includes night vision. They will be available in February for $79.99 and $99.99.

item.title: Configure a D-Link DCS-942L on Sensr.net
item.description:
The D-Link DCS-942L is a nice little camera from D-Link, an upgrade from its predecessor, the DCS-932L.  It works pretty well with Sensr.net if you know how to set it up.  For this camera you need to configure it to upload to Sensr.net on motion as it doesn’t support uploads at 1 FPS (frame per second).

Go to the camera’s UI and login as 

admin.  (By default the admin password isn’t set, so just hit return.)  Then go to the Setup page for Motion Detection, which should look something like this.  I put a red circle around the settings you want to choose.  Basically you want to select the Enable Video Motion option and tell the camera which part of the frame to use when detecting motion.

Next you need to tell the camera to FTP snapshots (JPEG images) to Sensr.net.  You’ll need the FTP credentials from your Sensr.net account for this camera.  You can get those by logging into Sensr.net and going to the settings page for your camera.

Get the FTP credentials from Sensr.net

Once you have the credentials, go to your DCS-942l page under Setup and then Snapshot and put the credentials in there.   Select the Snapshot mode and Trigger by Motion.  The path doesn’t really matter, but the port should be 21 and the Passive Mode should be selected, both of these are the defaults.  The screen on the camera side will look like this.

Tell your DSC-942l to upload snapshots on motion

Once you have your camera pushing snapshots to Sensr.net, you’ll be able to view the archives in our lovely cloud DVR view, where we organize them by month, day, and hour. Now you can easily find out what happened last night or last week with just a few clicks.

DVR View of DCS-942L

One drawback to the upload on motion is that the live view on Sensr.net won’t work, it will just show the last image we retrieved.  In the day view you’ll see missing images in the hours where there was no motion.   Not a big deal really, but it looks a little odd.  Here’s an example of the day view, you can see that nothing happened between midnight and 4am and that no images were stored between 8pm and midnight.

Day view example shows hours without motion.

Generally the DCS-942L is a decent camera and works pretty well with Sensr.net.  If you want the live view, you can always use the MyDlink site for that.

item.title: D-Link DCS-5222L “Cloud IP Camera” Launched
item.description:
D-Link’s new DCS-5222L was released last week, and it’s loaded with some pretty cool features, as well as some kind of confusing ones. You can get it on Amazon for about $250. We’ll start with the cool stuff first. The DCS-5222L is equipped with:

  • 1280×800 (HD) resolution at 30 FPS
  • Megapixel 1⁄4″ CMOS
  • Full PTZ
  • Night Vision up to 16 feet
  • H.264 Video Compression
  • Local Recording on micro-SD Card
  • Two-way Audio
  • MyDLink Enabled (like other D-Link cameras)
  • Easy Setup Process

The features are neat, and it’s not too bad of a deal for $250 — though you can get started with a Logitech Alert set for about the same price, if not a bit less. A few early reviews of the DCS-5222L suggest the Logitech Alert line is superior, but we haven’t tested D-Link’s new camera yet. We’ll try and get our hands on one in the future for a comparative review of our own.

On to the somewhat confusing stuff. The DCS-5222L is marketed around the web as a “cloud camera,” but it doesn’t actually store any video other than what’s on the micro-SD card. You can view the camera’s live feed from MyDLink, but you can do that with the 932L, 942L, etc. — there’s no actual cloud storage that I can find.

Sensr.net turns the DCS-5222L into a true cloud camera, where all motion events are recorded, stored, and available for later viewing. Of course, Sensr.net makes a great pair with MyDLink, as we’ve written about in the past. If you have already purchased the new DCS-5222L, get it up on Sensr.net and let us know what you think about it in the comments!

item.title: D-Link DCS-942L: Network Camera Deal of the Day
item.description:
D-Link’s upgraded DCS-942L is on sale at Amazon for $120. The 942L has a few upgraded features over its predecessor, the DCS-932L. For starters, the new IP camera is now equipped with a built-in microSD card reader allowing you to record video locally. It can store quite a bit more now that the video has the more efficient h.264 encoding versus MJPEG.

 The 942L also claims enhanced motion detection due to a passive infrared sensor. So if motion detection, local video recording, and live streaming in h.264 is worth the extra $30 over the 932L, head over to Amazon, and when you’ve got your shiny new 942L, make sure to put it on Sensr.net!

item.title: DCS-932L Sensr.net Survey Giveaway Winner
item.description: Congrats go out to Patrick from Manhattan Kansas, he filled out our survey earlier this month and was randomly chosen to win a D-Link DCS-932L IP camera. Thanks to all of you who filled out our survey, we realy appreciate it.  Some of you left requests in the survey, but we can’t connect users to specific survey results (bad monkey), so leave a comment here if you still have something to tell us about your Sensr.net account!

item.title: Win a Free D-Link DCS-932L by Following Sensr.net on Twitter
item.description:
[][1]Follow @sensr{.twitter-follow-button}

Want to win a free D-Link DCS-932L? All you have to do is follow Sensr.net (@sensr) on Twitter, and retweet one of our giveaway tweets to be eligible. Just click the link above to automatically follow us! Once we reach 500 followers, we’ll randomly select a winner. Shipping is included, but only where Amazon Prime will ship for free. Follow the link to see if you’re eligible.

item.title: Using MyDLink and Sensr.net Together
item.description:
MyDLink allows anyone with select D-Link network cameras to monitor their cameras remotely from an internet-connected computer, iPhone, iPad, and Android device for free. The web interface makes it easy to check your network camera’s status on the site, configure camera settings, manage multiple netcams under a single account, and watch live video with sound, though this will soak up a bit more bandwidth.

While MyDLink is loaded with numerous excellent features by itself, most notably being able to watch your camera’s video with audio, there are several great reasons to use Sensr.net alongside D-Link’s proprietary web software.

Watching live video for longer than a minute requires Universal Plug n Play (UPnP) to be enabled on your router. So if it’s not turned on, you’re stuck refreshing the site every minute to continue watching live video. Sensr.net allows you to view unlimited live video from your IP camera from any location, as well as on iPhone/iPad and Android devices, even behind a firewall.

0 seconds of live video remaining. Refresh!

MyDLink doesn’t provide motion detection notifications or image archiving, meaning if something amazing happens when you aren’t watching, the moment is gone and there’s no getting it back! Sensr.net tracks motion detection and can alert you via text or email when something happens, saving the images and organizing them by time/day. Check out these blog posts for more detail on how our camera motion detection settings work.

Though the D-ViewCam Surveillance Software does allow you to watch up 32 cameras on a single screen as well as record video, any saved images will be stored locally on your hard drive. Sensr.net saves all your network camera’s interesting captures (up to 600 images per hour) on our cloud, forever. Adding your D-Link network cameras to Sensr.net makes it easy to share your camera’s finest moments with your friends and family, and watch them from any place with an internet connection.

So what does this all add up to? If you’re sitting at your computer or using your mobile device to monitor your D-Link IP camera(s), using MyDLink’s live view with audio is an excellent option, assuming your router has UPnP enabled for unlimited video. But for times when you aren’t able to actively watch your camera feeds live, need motion detection notifications, or simply want to keep, or share the interesting things your camera captures, Sensr.net is a great solution.

You can check out some of the most popular D-Link IP cameras on Sensr.net below.

[

]2][4] YOLO Lounge (D Link DCS-930L)

And if you’re still on the fence about picking up a D-Link or a network camera at all, they’ve got a fun blog post on 7 non-creepy uses for IP cameras. Have fun!

item.title: D-Link DCS-932L Works Great on Sensr.net
item.description:
Accurate Daytime Color

D-Link has a new night vision camera called the DCS-932L.  This camera is very similar to their DCS-930L except that it does night vision.

Most night vision cameras in this price range have really bad daytime colors.  The DCS-932L doesn’t have this problem.  The night vision works great and the daytime images are also vibrant and accurate.

The  DCS-932L works great with Sensr.net.  If you want free archiving, sharing, and alerts along with your camera.  Get over to Sensr.net and add your camera there.  The Sensr.net setup for the DCS-932L is identical to the DCS-930L which we’ve covered already in this blog post.

Both the DCS-930L and the DCS-932L come with access to mydlink.com.  This service has been getting better too.  It now supports mobile access and no longer requires Internet Explorer.  I was able to view my cameras via Chrome on MacOS.   Of course you’ll need Sensr.net if you want archives, alerts, and social sharing of your camera content.  Sensr.net also gives you unlimited live viewing.  The mydlink.com site limits the live views to 60 seconds at at time.

Decent Night Vision
